messages.text:
Hi!

I have just released the <https://github.com/rvignolo/RayTracing.jl|RayTracing.jl> package, which computes cyclic ray tracing across any unstructured mesh in a rectangular domain. Its results are commonly used in Nuclear Reactor Physics, such as in the Collision Probability Method or the Method of Characteristics for solving the <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutron_transport#Neutron_transport_equation|Neutron Transport equation>. However, this information might be useful for some other subjects I am not familiar with and that is why I would like to share this with you. Also, I will start coding the Method of Characteristic now, anyone who wants to join is welcome!

elements.text:
Hi!

I have just released the
RayTracing.jl

package, which computes cyclic ray tracing across any unstructured mesh in a rectangular domain. Its results are commonly used in Nuclear Reactor Physics, such as in the Collision Probability Method or the Method of Characteristics for solving the
Neutron Transport equation

. However, this information might be useful for some other subjects I am not familiar with and that is why I would like to share this with you. Also, I will start coding the Method of Characteristic now, anyone who wants to join is welcome!

messages.text: Is there a package that can handle conversions between different coordinate systems for four vectors? Specifically, I am looking for something to convert E, p_T, eta, phi to t, x, y, z and back. Root's `TLorentzVector` can of course do this, but AFAIK, it doesn't really play nice with Julia.

attachments.fallback:
[February 20th, 2021 1:59 AM] contact691: Hello all. I've been trying to use `LsqFit` to fit a hyperbolic tangent function to some data about terminal velocity in free fall. Using SciPy's `curve_fit` function, it seems to work fine. However, in Julia, it's nowhere near the correct fit.
Here's the function I've written to fit the curve -
```function fit_terminal_velocity(data::CSV.File)
	# Create base model with random initial parameters
	p0 = rand(2)
	model(t, p) = p[1] .* tanh.(p[2]/p[1] .* t)
	
	# We are fitting v(t), so lets get those values
	# We also want to go from t = 0 to t = t_max
	t = data.t .- minimum(data.t)
	y = data.y
	
	v  = diff(y) ./ diff(t)
	tv = t[1:end-1]
	
	
	fitted_model = lsqfit.curve_fit(model, v, tv, p0)
	
	return fitted_model, model
end```
And it gives
```p[1] = -1.04293e-10
p[2] = 0.00917912```
Whereas Python gives `p = [-623.23056677, -319.5100746 ]` , which fit the model correctly. For reference, the code in python is
```f = lambda t, g, vt : vt * np.tanh(g/vt * t)
popts, pcov = curve_fit(f, t[1:], v)```
Where `curve_fit` is `scipy.optimize.curve_fit`.

I think it may be something to do with the fact that LsqFit requires `p0` but SciPy doesn't? I would really appreciate if anybody can help me figure out why curve fitting isn't working in Julia properly. Thank you so much!
attachments.text:
Hello all. I've been trying to use `LsqFit` to fit a hyperbolic tangent function to some data about terminal velocity in free fall. Using SciPy's `curve_fit` function, it seems to work fine. However, in Julia, it's nowhere near the correct fit.
Here's the function I've written to fit the curve -
```function fit_terminal_velocity(data::CSV.File)
	# Create base model with random initial parameters
	p0 = rand(2)
	model(t, p) = p[1] .* tanh.(p[2]/p[1] .* t)
	
	# We are fitting v(t), so lets get those values
	# We also want to go from t = 0 to t = t_max
	t = data.t .- minimum(data.t)
	y = data.y
	
	v  = diff(y) ./ diff(t)
	tv = t[1:end-1]
	
	
	fitted_model = lsqfit.curve_fit(model, v, tv, p0)
	
	return fitted_model, model
end```
And it gives
```p[1] = -1.04293e-10
p[2] = 0.00917912```
Whereas Python gives `p = [-623.23056677, -319.5100746 ]` , which fit the model correctly. For reference, the code in python is
```f = lambda t, g, vt : vt * np.tanh(g/vt * t)
popts, pcov = curve_fit(f, t[1:], v)```
Where `curve_fit` is `scipy.optimize.curve_fit`.

I think it may be something to do with the fact that LsqFit requires `p0` but SciPy doesn't? I would really appreciate if anybody can help me figure out why curve fitting isn't working in Julia properly. Thank you so much!

messages.text: I would really appreciate it if anybody knows how to do this and could help me. Thank you!

elements.text: I would really appreciate it if anybody knows how to do this and could help me. Thank you!

messages.text: Just use Optim.jl

elements.text: Just use Optim.jl

messages.text: Hello all! The issue was resolved. I have given a more detailed answer in the main thread, but TL;DR, use `p0 = ones(2)` rather than `p0 = rand(2)`

elements.text: Hello all! The issue was resolved. I have given a more detailed answer in the main thread, but TL;DR, use
p0 = ones(2)
rather than
p0 = rand(2)

messages.text: Works like a charm now

elements.text: Works like a charm now

messages.text:
<https://github.com/lebigot/uncertainties/issues/82>

> It would be great if you could add the capability of using complex numbers in `uncertainties`. This is available in the Julia package, `Measurements`, but I would prefer to have this capability available in Python. Thank you for considering.
I spent so much time to add support for complex numbers to `Measurements.jl` and they prefer to use the Python package... :cry:  oh, no, wait, that came for free thanks to multiple dispatch, I spent exactly 0 seconds to make complex numbers work

messages.text: I've been invited to do a Julia workshop at <https://indico.quarks.ru/event/2020> (under the label "advanced computing for particle physics"), and to ask around if others might be interested. Anyone want to join in?

attachments.title: QUARKS-2020  (31 May 2021 - 17 June 2021): Overview · Indico INR-TH (Indico)
attachments.text: The offline Seminar is postponed till 2022. The Organizing Committee decided to shift the offline “Quarks” seminar to June 5-11, 2022 due to ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. We will keep the same place of the Seminar (Pereslavl, Russia), the same program and spirit. Online Workshops in June 2021. In June 2021 we are planning to organize several online “Quarks” workshops based on the thematic sections in the original “Quarks-2020” program: Integrability, Holography, Higher-Spin Gravity and Strings...
